description: From Middle French trophée, from Latin trophaeum (“a sign of victory, a monument”), tropaeum, from Ancient Greek τρόπαιον (trópaion, “monument of an enemy's defeat”), from neuter of τροπαῖος (tropaîos, “of defeat”), from τροπή (tropḗ, “a rout, a turning of an enemy”).

entries.meaning: An object, usually in the form of a statuette, cup, or shield, awarded for success in a competition or to mark a special achievement.
examples: He won the trophy in a running competition.

entries.meaning: An object taken as a prize by a hunter or conqueror, especially one that is displayed.
examples: Around the posts hung helmets, darts, and spears, / And captive chariots, axes, shields, and bars, / And broken beaks of ships, the trophies of their wars.

entries.meaning: Any emblem of success; a status symbol.
examples: His trophies included his second wife, his successful children, the third and fourth homes in Palm Beach and Malibu, and his three yachts.

entries.meaning: (criminology, by extension) An object taken by a serial killer or rapist as a memento of the crime.

(art, architecture)  A display of weaponry and other militaria, often captured from a defeated enemy, as an ornament designed for the purpose of triumphalist display by a victor or as a show of military prowess by a monarch.
An artifact or artwork that has been stolen by a criminal and traded on the black market.
An animal killed by a trophy hunter that usually has its parts sold on the black market.

verbs.description: trophy (third-person singular simple present trophies, present participle trophying, simple past and past participle trophied)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To win a trophy in a competition.
